text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH2

text: DECEMBER 2020
label: BODY

text: 1     Because there are well-established and accepted standards and mechanisms for sharing financial information with donors, including a role for external
label: BODY

text: audits, requests for financial data are not included in this guidance note. This guidance note deals with sensitive personal and non-personal data.
label: BODY

text: 2    Roepstorff, K., Faltas, C. and Hövelmann, S., 2020. Counterterrorism Measures and Sanction Regimes: Shrinking Space for Humanitarian Aid
label: BODY

text: Organisations.
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH2

text: GUIDANCE NOTE SERIES
label: HH2

text: DATA RESPONSIBILITY IN HUMANITARIAN ACTION
label: HH2

text: RESPONSIBLE DATA SHARING WITH DONORS
label: HH1

text: KEY TAKEAWAYS:
label: HH2

text: •	 Sharing sensitive personal and non-personal data without adequate safeguards can exacerbate
label: BODY

text: risks for crisis-affected people, humanitarian organizations and donors.
label: BODY

text: •	 Donors regularly request data from the organizations they fund in order to fulfil their obligations
label: BODY

text: and objectives. Some of these requests relate to sensitive information and data which needs to
label: BODY

text: be protected in order to mitigate risk.
label: BODY

text: •	 Common objectives for data sharing with donors include: (i) situational awareness and
label: BODY

text: programme design; (ii) accountability and transparency; and (iii) legal, regulatory, and policy
label: BODY

text: requirements.
label: BODY

text: •	 Common constraints related to sharing data with donors include: (i) lack of regulatory framework
label: BODY

text: for responsibly managing sensitive non-personal data; (ii) capacity gaps; and (iii) purpose
label: BODY

text: limitation.
label: BODY

text: •	 Donors and humanitarian organizations can take the following steps to minimize risks while
label: BODY

text: maximizing benefits when sharing sensitive data: (i) reviewing and clarifying the formal or
label: BODY

text: informal frameworks that govern the collection and sharing of disaggregated data; (ii) formalizing
label: BODY

text: and standardising requests for sensitive data; (iii) investing in data management capacities of
label: BODY

text: staff and organisations; and (iv) adopting common principles for donor data management.
label: BODY

text: INTRODUCTION
label: HH2

text: Donors have an important role in the humanitarian data ecosystem, both as drivers of increased data
label: BODY

text: collection and analysis, and as direct users of data. This is not a new phenomenon; the need for
label: BODY

text: accountability and transparency in the use of donor funding is broadly understood and respected. However,
label: BODY

text: in recent years, donors have begun requesting data that can be sensitive. This includes personal data about
label: BODY

text: beneficiaries and various forms of disaggregated data, such as household-level survey results and data
label: BODY

text: about the delivery of assistance disaggregated by demographic and/or group dimensions (e.g. ethnicity,
label: BODY

text: protection group, etc.).1
label: BODY

text: Concerns around requests for such data have led donors and humanitarian organizations to place more
label: BODY

text: emphasis on identifying strategies for data responsibility: the safe, ethical and effective management
label: BODY

text: of data. Data responsibility requires donors and humanitarian organizations to take actions that help
label: BODY

text: minimize risks while maximizing benefits of data. This is particularly challenging in cases where donors
label: BODY

text: request sensitive data. For example, the screening of aid recipients, which is often used to justify requests
label: BODY

text: for personal data, is not only difficult to practically implement, but also highly problematic in terms of
label: BODY

text: principled aid.2
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH2

text: DECEMBER 2020
label: BODY

text: 3   Non-personal data is defined as data which was initially personal data, but later made anonymous, such as data about the people affected by the
label: BODY

text: humanitarian situation and their needs, the threats and vulnerabilities they face, and their capacities (adapted from Regulation (EU)
label: BODY

text: 2018/1807 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 14 November 2018 on a framework for the free flow of non-personal data in the
label: BODY

text: European Union).
label: BODY

text: 4   See the Working Draft OCHA Guidelines for Data Responsibility and the ICRC Handbook on data protection in humanitarian action.
label: BODY

text: 5   Read more about the virtual dialogue in this Wilton Park Report.
label: BODY

text: 6  Willits-King, B. and Spencer, A., 2020. Responsible data-sharing with donors: accountability, transparency and data protection in principled
label: BODY

text: humanitarian action.
label: BODY

text: 7   At the time of writing, only USAID and GIZ had publicly available guidelines on responsible data sharing. See USAID, 2019. Considerations for using
label: BODY

text: data responsibly at USAID and GIZ, 2018. GIZ’s Responsible Data Principles.
label: BODY

text: 8   Willits-King, B. and Spencer, A., 2020. Responsible data-sharing with donors: accountability, transparency and data protection in principled
label: BODY

text: humanitarian action.
label: BODY

text: In addition, sharing seemingly innocuous data such as aggregated survey results can place already
label: BODY

text: vulnerable people and communities at greater risk. What may be initially considered non-personal data3
label: BODY

text: can allow for re-identification of individuals, communities and demographic groups. Re-identification
label: BODY

text: occurs when data can be traced back or linked to an individual(s) or group(s) of individuals because it is not
label: BODY

text: adequately anonymized. This can result in a violation of data protection, privacy and other human rights
label: BODY

text: and can allow for targeting of individuals or groups with violence or other forms of harm.4
label: BODY

text: Many donors and humanitarian actors recognize the risks and benefits associated with sharing such
label: BODY

text: sensitive data, but the sector has yet to establish a common understanding of how to balance these risks
label: BODY

text: and benefits effectively. Recent efforts to address this issue have led to more clarity on current practices,
label: BODY

text: as well as on the objectives and constraints of data sharing. In September 2020, the Government of
label: BODY

text: Switzerland, the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) and the United Nations Office for
label: BODY

text: Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (UN OCHA) Centre for Humanitarian Data (the Centre) organized a
label: BODY

text: virtual Wilton Park dialogue to help build common understanding on this issue.5
label: BODY

text: This guidance note synthesizes the outcomes of this dialogue and a related desk review.6 It describes the
label: BODY

text: challenges around sharing sensitive data with donors and offers initial recommendations for how donors
label: BODY

text: and humanitarian organizations can more effectively navigate this area.
label: BODY

text: DONOR REQUESTS FOR DATA
label: HH2

text: Donors regularly request data from their partners in order to fulfil different obligations and objectives.
label: BODY

text: These requests can be either formal or informal.
label: BODY

text: •	 Formal requests tend to be included in grant agreements in relation to reporting criteria, and are
label: BODY

text: typically based on legal requirements such as compliance with counter-terrorism laws. Such requests
label: BODY

text: tend to be negotiated at the outset of a partnership or grant agreement, and are usually made in
label: BODY

text: writing and scheduled in advance.
label: BODY

text: •	 Informal requests concern information or data that typically fall outside of the normal scope  of
label: HH3

text: reporting. These ad-hoc requests often carry implicit value, meaning that while they are not
label: BODY

text: formally required, delivering this supplementary data is deemed beneficial for an organization’s
label: BODY

text: ongoing engagement and partnership with a donor. These requests represent a greater dilemma for
label: BODY

text: humanitarian actors.
label: BODY

text: Few donors have formal data sharing policies or guidelines in place.7 There is also a lack of shared
label: BODY

text: understanding of terminology and of the objectives and risks around data sharing. There are different
label: BODY

text: definitions and understanding of data-related risks, leading to inconsistent and sometimes contradictory
label: BODY

text: practices around sharing potentially sensitive data with donors in a particular context.8
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH2

text: DECEMBER 2020
label: BODY

text: 9   See NRC's Toolkit for Principled Humanitarian Action; Managing CT Risks.
label: BODY

text: 10 In order to ensure compliance, donors might request highly disaggregated data to corroborate their due diligence processes, ensuring their partners
label: BODY

text: are not engaging with any ‘sanctioned’ person or entity’. See Walker, J., 2020. Compliance Dialogue on Syria-Related Humanitarian Payments.
label: BODY

text: ‘Sanctioned persons’ is a general term which may include individuals, terrorist groups, governments as well as companies and other entities of legal
label: BODY

text: personality. The EU, for example, has over the years considerably strengthened its legal framework for preventing money laundering and terrorism
label: BODY

text: financing in recent years and is constantly enforcing in. See: NGO Voice, 2020. The Impact of EU Sanctions and Restrictive Measures on
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian Action.
label: BODY

text: 11  Inter-Agency Standing Committee (IASC) Humanitarian Financing Task Team (HFTT), 2016. Donor Conditions and their implications for
label: BODY

text: humanitarian response.
label: BODY

text: 12 Publish What You Fund, 2020. Data Use Capacity in Protracted Humanitarian Crises.
label: BODY

text: CONSTRAINTS FOR DATA SHARING WITH DONORS
label: HH3

text: Despite these objectives, data sharing with donors is not without its constraints, which include a lack of
label: BODY

text: regulatory frameworks for responsibly managing sensitive non-personal data, capacity gaps and lack of
label: BODY

text: purpose limitation.
label: BODY

text: Lack of regulatory frameworks for responsibly managing sensitive non-personal data
label: BODY

text: The sensitivity of personal data is generally well-known and addressed by a variety of policy and regulatory
label: BODY

text: frameworks, but the same cannot be said for sensitive non-personal data. Protecting groups and their
label: BODY

text: data remains challenging due to the current gaps in regulation and guidance and the overall lack of
label: BODY

text: understanding regarding the sensitivity of non-personal data. These data policy gaps increase the risk of
label: BODY

text: sensitive data not being stored or protected adequately or shared inadvertently by partners in order to
label: BODY

text: satisfy donors’ requests.
label: BODY

text: Capacity gaps
label: HH3

text: Responding to ad-hoc data sharing requests from donors can be viewed as an additional burden to
label: BODY

text: humanitarian responders, diverting critical time, resources and focus away from other implementing
label: BODY

text: activities.11 Insufficient funding for data-related capacity development has limited many organizations’
label: BODY

text: ability to provide their staff with the skills and resources required for managing data responsibly.12 Gaps
label: BODY

text: in capacity to fulfil donor requirements might also deter smaller and/or local NGOs from seeking funding,
label: BODY

text: undermining localization efforts.13
label: BODY

text: OBJECTIVES FOR DATA SHARING WITH DONORS
label: HH3

text: The most commonly identified objectives for donors requesting sensitive data from partners are
label: BODY

text: situational awareness and programme design; accountability and transparency; and legal, regulatory, and
label: BODY

text: policy requirements.
label: BODY

text: Situational awareness and programme design
label: BODY

text: Donors seek information and data from humanitarian organizations in order to understand and react
label: BODY

text: to changes in humanitarian contexts. This allows donors to improve their own programme design and
label: BODY

text: evaluation, prevent duplication of assistance, identify information gaps, and ensure appropriate targeting
label: BODY

text: of assistance.
label: BODY

text: Accountability and transparency
label: HH3

text: Donors and humanitarian organizations have an obligation to account for their activities. Data can enable
label: BODY

text: donors to explain and defend funding on foreign aid to taxpayers.
label: BODY

text: Legal, regulatory, and policy requirements
label: HH3

text: Donors are subject to certain national and international legal requirements, including political, legal and
label: BODY

text: statutory requirements related to counter-terrorism, migration and law enforcement. In many cases,
label: BODY

text: donors might want to use data to verify their compliance with these different requirements. Some donors
label: BODY

text: include counterterrorism clauses in their grant agreements, which are intended to ensure that their funds
label: BODY

text: are not used to benefit designated terrorist groups.9 Similarly, donors might include clauses to cover anti-
label: BODY

text: bribery, anti-fraud and anti-corruption measures.10
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH2

text: DECEMBER 2020
label: BODY

text: 14  ICRC, 2020. Handbook on data protection in humanitarian action.
label: BODY

text: 15  Examples include the Good Humanitarian Donorship Initiative and the Grand Bargain.
label: BODY

text: RECOMMENDATIONS
label: H4

text: In view of the objectives and constraints detailed above, the Centre, the Humanitarian Policy Group (HPG)
label: BODY

text: at ODI, the ICRC, and the Human Security Division of the Swiss Federal Department of Foreign Affairs
label: BODY

text: recommend that donors and humanitarian organizations take the following steps to minimize risks while
label: BODY

text: maximizing benefits when sharing sensitive data:
label: BODY

text: •	 Reviewing and clarifying the formal or informal frameworks that govern the collection and
label: HH3

text: sharing of disaggregated data
label: BODY

text: Donors and partners should examine the official, formal requirements and ad-hoc, informal
label: BODY

text: requirements of data sharing, and analyse partner and donor staff interpret whether requirements
label: BODY

text: correctly and consistently. They should assess whether there are implicit conditionalities between the
label: BODY

text: willingness to share disaggregated data and the ability of different organizations to access and sustain
label: BODY

text: funding from donors.
label: BODY

text: •	 Formalizing and standardizing requests for sensitive data
label: HH3

text: When sensitive data is required to meet a mutually agreed objective, donors should formalize and
label: BODY

text: standardize their requests for such data. Requests should be made in writing and should specify
label: BODY

text: which data is requested, the format desired, and the intended use of the data. Donors should only
label: BODY

text: request the information required to meet the specified purpose for which it is being requested and
label: BODY

text: should indicate a timeline for destruction of the data. Humanitarian organisations should document
label: BODY

text: all requests for data and ensure consistency in responding to these requests over time.
label: BODY

text: •	 Investing in data management capacities of staff and organizations
label: HH3

text: Donors and humanitarian organizations should identify opportunities to invest in building data
label: BODY

text: management expertise especially for non-technical staff. The donor community is uniquely positioned
label: BODY

text: to encourage data responsibility by  providing additional  resources for training and capacity building.
label: BODY

text: •	 Adopting common principles for donor data management
label: HH3

text: The sector already has a range of principles and commitments to inform different aspects of
label: BODY

text: humanitarian donorship.15 However, these do not sufficiently address concerns related to data
label: BODY

text: responsibility. Donors and partners should engage in the development of common principles and
label: BODY

text: guidelines for donor data sharing to fill this gap. The Humanitarian Data and Trust Initiative, co-led
label: BODY

text: by the Government of Switzerland, the ICRC, and the Centre, offers a platform to facilitate this process
label: BODY

text: as part of its ongoing work to build trust through dialogue.
label: BODY

text: Organizations are encouraged to share their experience in responsible data sharing with donors with the
label: BODY

text: Centre for Humanitarian Data via centrehumdata@un.org.
label: BODY

text: Purpose limitation
label: BODY

text: The principle of purpose limitation requires that data is only collected for specified, explicit and legitimate
label: BODY

text: purposes, and that it not be processed further in a manner that would be incompatible with those
label: BODY

text: purposes.14 Even when donors specify legitimate reasons for requesting data in-line with the original
label: BODY

text: purposes for which the data was collected (e.g. the delivery of humanitarian assistance), it can be difficult
label: BODY

text: to ensure that the data will not be used for other purposes once shared. Data used out of context and for
label: BODY

text: purposes that are not known at the time of sharing, or retained past the intended retention for a defined
label: BODY

text: purpose represents a violation, even if unintended, of the data subjects’ rights.
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH2

text: COLLABORATORS: THE HUMANITARIAN POLICY GROUP AT ODI; INTERNATIONAL COMMITTEE OF THE RED CROSS;
label: BODY

text: AND THE HUMAN SECURITY DIVISION, SWISS FEDERAL DEPARTMENT OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS.
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data ('the Center'), together with key partners, is publishing a series of eight
label: BODY

text: guidance notes on Data Responsibility in Humanitarian Action over the course of 2019 and 2020. The Guidance
label: BODY

text: Note series follows the publication of the OCHA Data Responsibility Guidelines in March 2019. Through
label: BODY

text: the series, the Centre aims to provide additional guidance on specific issues, processes and tools for data
label: BODY

text: responsibility in practice. This series is made possible with the generous support of the Directorate-General for
label: BODY

text: European Civil Protection and Humanitarian Aid Operations (DG ECHO).
label: BODY
